required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intravenous Versus Subcutaneous Administration of Low Molecular Weight Heparin for Thromboprophylaxis in Critically Ill Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Intravenous Versus Subcutaneous Administration of Low Molecular Weight Heparin for Thromboprophylaxis in Critically Ill Patients: a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Objective: To compare the pharmacokinetic profiles of intravenous versus subcutaneous route of administration of LMWH for thromboprophylaxis in critically ill patients

detailed_description.textblock: The study is a prospective, monocentric, randomized trial. Patients are randomized to the IV route of administration over a 4-hours infusion of nadroparin 3800 IU or to the SC route of administration. Randomization is stratified according to the need for vasopressor or not. Anti-Xa activity is measured at baseline, and at 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 12 and 24 hours after the administration was started.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Peak anti-Xa activity obtained 4 hours after start of low molecular weight heparin administration
primary_outcome.description: Peak anti-Xa activity obtained 4 hours after start of low molecular weight heparin administration

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Trough anti-Xa activity measured 24 hours after start of low molecular weight administration
secondary_outcome.description: Trough anti-Xa activity measured 24 hours after start of low molecular weight administration
Area under the curve 0-24 hours of anti-Xa activity after start of low molecular weight heparin

intervention.description: Intravenous route of administration over a 4-hours infusion of nadroparin 3800 IU
Subcutaneous route of administration of nadroparin 3800 IU

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults patients > 18 years old admitted in the ICU, and for whom thromboprophylaxis is indicated
Exclusion Criteria:
- renal failure determined by glomerular filtration rate (GFR) < 30 ml/min or need for renal replacement therapy
- liver cirrhosis
- intravascular disseminated coagulation
- contra-indication to thromboprophylaxis for any reason as decided by the treating physician, or indication for therapeutic dosing anticoagulation (recent thrombo-embolic event, atrial fibrillation,…)
- patients receiving low dose of vasopressor (norepinephrine < 0.25 mcg/kg/min) to allow stratification and comparison between patients not on vasopressors and patients with a significant dose of vasopressors (norepinephrine ≥ 0.25 mcg/kg/min)
